title: How can it be said that God loves everyone, but yet so many people are born in such horrible circumstances, through no fault of their own

author: allgutennombrestaken
text:
>If God truly loved everyone the same, and showed no bias, then people would be born in the same circumstances.

Only if everyone was totally identical. But each one of us is unique and born (or not born) into the circumstance that is ultimately the most beneficial for them

author: Timthechoochoo
text: So what's beneficial about a baby being born with harlequin syndrome for instance? Or a five year old starving to death?

author: Calx9
text:
I've asked this for years. I always get the same bullshit answer. It's our fault for bringing sin into the world. Natural evil exists because mankind couldn't obey God. It's the worst answer I've heard to anything ever honestly.


They honestly believe bone cancer in children should exist because we Adam and Eve ate that apple. It's the most outrageous logic.

author: Timthechoochoo
text:
Yes and it's a ridiculous cop-out. It isn't the five year old's fault for "bringing sin into the world".

It's outrageous what generally nice people will say when they're trying to defend these ancient beliefs.

author: allgutennombrestaken
text: Clearly you've exclusively asked christians then

author: Calx9
text: Oh, yes. Absolutely talking only about Christians. Sorry shoulda been more clear. I spend over 20-40 hours over at r/Christianity a week so please forgive me.

author: allgutennombrestaken
text: It's all good. It happens to the best of us

author: allgutennombrestaken
text: I don't know. Maybe the soul agreed to it in advance so that it would reap the rewards of the good acts that its death inspired. Or maybe that person did something in a previous life that made it deserve it.

author: BobertMcGee
text:
Do you actually believe that nonsense or are you pulling “maybes” out of your ass?

I’ve got one: _maybe_ bad things happen to good people and your religion is just one big cope because you can’t put on your big boy pants and face the world as it is.

author: allgutennombrestaken
text:
I believe that those explain some if not all of the cases and that those that it doesn't explain are equally justified through explanations I haven't heard/thought of

>maybe bad things happen to good people and your religion is just one big cope because you can’t put on your big boy pants and face the world as it is.

maybe but I doubt it. I didn't come to my religion because it has these answers. They're just part of why I haven't dropped it

author: Timthechoochoo
text: Lol okay buddy.

author: DAb0ssz
text: God, being all-knowing, understands how that person suffering since born can help other people, maybe that situation makes the family reconciliate, or the five year old starving to death inspires the creation of a foundation. A kid suffered, yes, it's sad and it's horrible, but it may help to a greater good.

author: Timthechoochoo
text:
There's no other way to "make a family reconcile" than to murder their kid? If he's all-knowing, then surely he KNOWS another way to do this.

You can say "maybe" all you want, but if you know anybody who has lost a child it does the polar opposite of what you said. It rips peoples' lives and families apart and can even make people kill themselves. This is just an unfathomable mental gymnastic you're pulling to justify any type of atrocity as "good somehow"

author: DAb0ssz
text:
I mean, surely there are other ways to make a family reconciliate, but this one, in the circumstances of the people, culture, etc. May be the best one.

And of course, shit like that destroy lives and isn't something nice to experiment, but things that at first seem terrible and dangerous are later helpful, maybe not for the ones affected, but for later generations and people. A child suffers and that's horrible, and that breaks down it's family, but an all-knowing god understands how this horrible situation could benefit the family's neighbours, or the second cousin of the children's mother, etc. Life is too complex and the destructive consequences of that death, could lead to a well-being of more people than the ones who where affected.

author: Timthechoochoo
text:
So is anything actually bad? Maybe Hitler was good in the longrun because he taught us to love each other more or some shit.

The way you're excusing bad things makes it so that there's no discernable difference between good things and bad things.

author: DAb0ssz
text:
There is a discernable difference. Killing an innocent is bad, even if it benefits the whole planet, the act of taking the life of someone with hopes, intentions, fears, passions, etc. Is bad.

Killing that person is bad, but it would help the whole world, that makes the act of killing him less evil? Not, but in this situation the end justifies the means. Killing that person stills bad, but what is better: More life quality for the whole world or one individual person and it's family/close ones?

author: Timthechoochoo
text:
So if a kid, Jerry, dies because another person shoots him, this is bad and you don't try and look at the bright side. But if Jerry dies due to a volcano, and the same benefits of his death occur, now it's "apart of god's plan". Well maybe the guy killing Jerry was apart of the plan - you should try and see the good in it.

"Killing an innocent is bad, even if it benefits the whole planet, the act of taking the life of someone with hopes, intentions, fears, passions, etc. Is bad."

A kid who dies of starvation also had hopes, intentions, fears, passions, etc. Is this still bad because another person didn't purposefully kill him?

author: DAb0ssz
text:
The death of a person is always sad and tragic, but in your volcanoe example, even though the death is depressing, you can't give moral judgements to nature. Is that volcanoe death part of the plan of god? Well, everything is part of the plan of god in a way or another.

And yes, if a kid dies of starvation is bad, why? Because starvation isn't a natural catastrophe, if humans didn't were corrupt, or weren't in a civil war, etc, etc, the kid could've lived, his death is product of human evilness.

author: Timthechoochoo
text:
Why are moral judgements relevant to this at all? Why is God exempt from moral judgements for allowing children to be massacred by the forces of nature which he controls?

Dude. Why are you dodging? Are you saying any kid who has died of starvation is the result of human affairs? How about being born in a dreary wasteland that doesn't have food?

This is what I'm saying. Theists are forced to make unbelievable excuses. Starvation isn't a person's fault. It's an unfortunate natural phenomena that affects all organisms regardless of "corruption". You can't blame EVERYTHING on "human corruption".

The point of this thread is to ask **how is god all-loving** if he lets these things happen. A volcano is God's creation. He created volcanos that explode and kill things. Why did he do this?

author: hummingelephant
text:
So you mean we should wish you and your children a horrible life and life altering accident and that all your children be born with diseases...so you can be a benefit to this world?

I guess: may you and your family suffer greatly...? ...

author: DAb0ssz
text:
Definitely not.
Bad things still bad even if are beneficial someway.
I wouldn't want diseases or accidents in my family, because those things are harsh experiences, but I think that is better saying: This can lead to a greater good, than falling in a pit of desperation.

author: BobertMcGee
text: I don’t think even you believe what you just said. A child born to an alcoholic mother and an abusive father was not born into an environment most beneficial to them.

author: allgutennombrestaken

author: BobertMcGee
text:
What you’re saying is just plain false, ON TOP of being downright evil. Suffering from abuse and disability is the worst way to prepare someone for the hardships of life. We _know_ that children born into poverty and abusive homes grow up with worse life outcomes. We’ve studied the hell out of this and if what you’re claiming were remotely true we’d see that the happiest, healthiest, most productive, and most well adjusted people would be coming from the most difficult childhoods. The opposite is true.

Explain to me how a 5 year old who dies of unspeakably painful leukemia was born into a circumstance most beneficial to them. You’re essentially telling us we should be _thankful_ for trauma. Fuck that. How dare you?

author: allgutennombrestaken
text:

You cannot possibly know that.

a very very good person can still be sad and unhealthy

in what sense?

Maybe they'll be compensated in the afterlife for being the impetus for the parents, relatives, or others who do good as a result of their death. Maybe they did something in a previous life that made them deserve it.

>You’re essentially telling us we should be thankful for trauma

absolutely not. that's a very high level of person that can be thankful for their suffering and it's not expected of anyone. Certainly of the suffering of others we are commanded to empathize and help in any way we can
